newsitem.title: MALAYSIA: Malaysia's Mahathir says no need to weaken ringgit.
newsitem.headline: Malaysia's Mahathir says no need to weaken ringgit.

text.p: Malaysia's Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad said on Tuesday there was no need to weaken the ringgit.
"I don't see the need to lower the ringgit," he told reporters at an energy conference.
"I don't like the manipulation of the currency to the point where we lose control," he said when asked if the country would let the currency weaken.
He said the ringgit was a convertible currency whose value was affected by movement of other currencies, but there was excessive speculation in the Malaysian unit.
"The deliberate move to lower the value of the ringgit is just to make more money," he said.
Reporters were seeking clarification to his comments in New York last week, which had caused a sharp fall in the ringgit.
Mahathir said in New York he believed in the need for a "competitive exchange rate" that reflects what he called "long-term market forces".
Dealers quoted Mahathir as reaffirming that central bank intervention in foreign exchange market would be limited to smoothing out sharp short-term fluctuations.
